Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Formation of thin films with self-assembled monolayers embedded on their surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
In many applications, thin films are coated onto the surface of materials to modify their mechanical, thermal, electrical, and optical properties. The coatings must be highly ordered two-dimensional crystals with a specific lattice spacing which is application dependent. For example, to make a highly-efficient anti-reflection coating for solar cells, the surface is textured with a periodic pattern with the wavelength comparable to that of solar radiation. This can be achieved by coating the surface by a thin film with a monolayer of particles embedded on its surface. The particle size and the spacing between particles can be selected for obtaining the desired pattern. These particle coated thin films can also be used for making masks for nano-lithography, textured hydrophobic surfaces, and membrane filters with regular pores. The membrane filters could be used to precisely control the mass transfer rate of a drug-delivery patch, and to separate proteins and other macromolecules based on their sizes.

Capillarity-driven clustering at fluid interfaces is a well-established method for forming monolayers, but those monolayers are poorly ordered. In the proposed technique an electric field in the direction normal to the interface is applied to control the self-assembly process so to obtain a virtually defect-free monolayer of electrically neutral nano-particles. When there are two or more types of particles present, there is a hierarchical order in the assembled monolayers which can be optimized by selecting a suitable fluid. The technique also allows us to vary the lattice spacing as appropriate to the application. The monolayer is then frozen onto the surface of a thin flexible film which can be transferred to the surface of a material to modify its surface properties. The technique is easy to implement and can be applied to a broad range of particle sizes and types with a high level of controllability which will be advantageous in many applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project is to commercialize our scalable and cost effective technology for forming thin films with a monolayer (single layer) of particles embedded on their surfaces. Particles can be of nanometers to 100s of microns in size, and they can be dielectric or metallic. These flexible thin films can be bonded onto the surface of a material to modify its mechanical, thermal, electrical and optical properties. These films have applications in lithography, biosensor arrays, templated self-assembly of nano-structured materials, and in biological processes as textured surfaces for enhancing cell growth, and also for making porous membranes with precisely defined pore sizes for controlled drug delivery and pharmaceutical applications. The technique is scalable and cost-effective.

 

When we started the I-CORPS program, we wanted to explore the viability of launching a scalable startup for our technology which will focus on the following three market segments: anti-reflection coatings (ARC) for solar cells, customized surface patterns for lithography, and porous membranes with precisely defined pore sizes for controlled drug delivery and pharmaceutical applications. We got out of the building and talked to about 100 customers in these segments, and based on these interviews we decided to focus on only the latter two of these segments.

 

The photomask market is big; we have decided to focus on photomasks with simple features for which we can provide higher quality at a lower cost. We have validated our value proposition that there is a need for a cost effective way for making simple masks with micron and sub-micron patterns. For bio-pharmaceutical applications, we were not able to conduct sufficient number of interviews during the I-Corps course to validate our value proposition as this sector is too diverse. After the completion of the course, we have continued to work on validating our value proposition that there is a need for a cost effective way for making biosensor arrays with periodic sub-micron patterns. We have discovered that there is interest in making monolayers of 500-600 nm gold particles for surface enhanced the resonance Raman scattering (SERS) applications. This is a new application which has grown considerably in the past few years. Our technology is well suited for embedding gold particles onto the surface of a semiconductor film and controlling their inter-particle distance. We have successfully made substrates (MVPs) for SERS and are working with a collaborator on testing their effectiveness.

 

The capabilities of our technology have been disseminated broadly through direct contacts with potential customers, presentations in trade shows and international conferences, and publications in international scientific journals. The project has resulted in two patents applications and a technology disclosure. The entrepreneurial skills acquired during this project have been incorporated in the PI’s courses and research. We have recently started to explore the possibility of commercializing another technology developed in our group. The graduate student working on this project, our Entrepreneurial Lead, has been trained in evaluating the potential market value of a technology and in the skills required for launching a scalable startup.
